Graphical abstract This review focuses on the various high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts with specific construction strategies, desired induced effects, enhanced catalytic mechanism in the alkaline OER electrocatalysis. Electrocatalysis for the oxygen evolution reactions (OER) has attracted much attention due to its important role in water splitting and rechargeable metal-air batteries. Therefore, designing highly efficient and low-cost catalysts for OER process is essential as the conventional catalysts still rely on precious metals. Transition metal-based compounds have been widely investigated as active OER catalysts, and renewed interest in the high valence metals engineered compounds has been achieved for superior catalytic activity and stability. However, an in-depth understanding of the construction strategies and induced effects for the high valence metals engineered catalysts is still lacking and desired. In this review, we have summarized the construction strategies of high valence metals as dopants or formed heterostructures with the iron/cobalt/nickel (Fe/Co/Ni)-based catalysts. Then the induced effects on Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts by incorporating high valence metals, e.g., accelerating the surface reconstruction, forming amorphous structure, generating vacancies/defects, and acting as stabilizers, are highlighted. The impacts of high valence metals on OER performance are elucidated based on different elements, including molybdenum (Mo), tungsten (W), cerium (Ce), vanadium (V), chromium (Cr), manganese (Mn), niobium (Nb), zirconium (Zr). The correlations of construction strategies, induced effects, catalytic activity and OER reaction pathways are elaborated. Finally, the remaining challenges for further enhancements of OER performance induced by high valence metals are presented. Keywords High valence metals Construction strategies Induced effect Oxygen evolution reactions 1 Introduction The rapid development of our society results in urgent environmental pollution and energy crisis, which stimulates the efforts to investigate renewable energy storage and conversion [1–4]. Hydrogen with high energy, clean, and renewable properties, has emerged as a very competitive and promising candidate for fossil fuels [5–7]. However, large-scale production of hydrogen is still limited by the synthesis approach, which heavily relies on steam reforming of natural gas, inevitably resulting in the emissions of carbon dioxide. Electrochemical water splitting, on the other hand, is an alternative and facile way to generate hydrogen with zero carbon emissions [8]. Water splitting process involves two main reactions, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode. The sluggish kinetics of OER due to the multistep electron transfer process mainly impede the industrial scale application [9–14]. In addition, OER is also an important reaction involved in rechargeable metal-air batteries, which is one of the most promising energy conversion and storage devices [15–19]. The practical application of metal-air batteries is greatly limited by the slow kinetics of OER and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) processes, which highly decrease the high-rate discharge and power density [20–26]. Thus, it is vital and desired to design highly efficient and stable electrocatalysts for OER to boost both the overall water splitting and metal-air battery processes. It is undoubted that the precious metals, represented by ruthenium (Ru) and iridium (Ir)-based catalysts, exhibit outstanding OER catalytic activity [27–32]. Nevertheless, the high cost and low distribution limit their further large-scale application [33–37]. Alternatively, Fe/Co/Ni-based materials have exhibited promising catalytic capability for OER in alkaline electrolytes as their abundant reserves, low cost, and excellent activity. The unique electronic structure of Fe/Co/Ni enables them to have moderate chemical bond strength with the intermediates of electrocatalysis, so they perform well as catalysts in heterogeneous catalytic reactions such as OER. Since the bond strength between the active sites and reactants/intermediates plays an important role in OER activity, optimizing the structure and combination of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts is conducive to the electrocatalysis process [38–43]. For instance, porous cobalt oxide nanoplates synthesized by ligand-assisted polyol reduction method achieved promising OER performance with a low overpotential of 306 mV for the current density of 10 mA cm−2 [44]. In addition, Fe doped β-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets also exhibited excellent OER catalytic performance with the overpotential of 219 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, ascribing to their special crumpled nanosheets network and the special microstructure with crystal/amorphous interface, which facilitated the gas release and provided unsaturated coordination environment for optimizing the adsorption of OER reactants/intermediates [45]. Although the intrinsic properties of Fe/Co/Ni-based materials are suitable for OER, their catalytic activity is still far from satisfactory. Many efforts have been devoted to developing transition metal-based materials for highly efficient OER via various modification strategies, such as morphology tuning, defect engineering, incorporation of non-metal or metal elements, etc., which induce specific properties and appealing catalytic capability. The non-noble high valence metals engineering strategies have achieved excellent results in the OER electrocatalysis. Firstly, Fe/Co/Ni is mostly composed of +2 or +3 valence state, so Co3+ and Ni3+, Fe3+ can be determined as high valence metal sites. Similarly, these transition metals further to be oxidized to Co4+, Ni4+, and Fe4+ in the OER process are also high valence metal sites [46]. The Fe/Co/Ni is more stable at their low valence state, whereas the corresponding high valence states usually reveal better OER catalytic activity [47–49]. For example, Co3+ on the surface of Co3O4 crystal was responsible the boosted OER performance [50]. In addition, Ni(OH)2 gradually converted to NiOOH during OER process, which was the real active sites for the enhanced activity [51]. Compared with Fe/Co/Ni, other 3d, 4d and 5d transition metals (e.g., V [52], Cr [53,54], Mn [55,56], Mo [57,58], W [59,60], Nb [61,62], Zr [63], etc.) normally exhibit higher valence, hence their oxidation state is also defined as high-valence metal sites. This review will mainly focus on these high valence metals (non-noble metals) other than Co, Ni, Fe [64]. These high valence metal elements themselves usually do not show satisfactory OER catalytic activity. However, they are expected to enhance the inherent catalytic capacity of Fe/Co/Ni-based materials [60,65–67]. Introducing high valence metals into Fe/Co/Ni-based materials has been widely studied and applied, which can make the original catalysts produce various outstanding functions to achieve efficient OER performance. For instance, introducing Mo6+ into trimetallic FeCoMo nanocomposite can result in charge redistribution from 3d transition metals to Mo atoms, forming high valence metals sites of Co3+ and Fe3+ [57]. Furthermore, the strong electronic interaction between Mo and Fe is conductive to the increase of octahedral structure distortion around Fe atoms, which is also responsible for the enhanced OER performance [68–71]. Therefore, high valence metals can not only stabilize Fe/Co/Ni at relatively higher valence states but also induce the electronic effect to further enhance the OER catalytic activity, which is a promising strategy to design highly efficient OER catalysts for future industrial applications. Numerous studies have shown that high valence metals engineering has a significant effect on OER performance. In recent years, there have been a lot of discussions and summaries on Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts, but a comprehensive summary of the design strategy of high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based-OER catalysts is lacking and desired [72–75]. Herein, we mainly focus on the progress of high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for the boosted OER electrocatalysis in alkaline media and provide an overview of the relationship among the construction strategies, induced effects, and catalytic performance (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, we briefly introduced the relevant OER catalytic mechanisms to provide an understanding of the catalysts design. Then, the construction strategies for the high valence metals-based catalysts have been discussed, including the high valence metals as dopants and heterostructures constructed between the high valence metal compounds and Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. Then, the corresponding induced effects caused by the incorporation of high valence metals will be summarized, including accelerating the surface reconstruction, the formation of amorphous structure, induced vacancies/defects, and acting as catalyst stabilizers. Moreover, we will focus on the various high valence metals (Mo, W, Ce, V, Cr, Mn, Nb, Zr) engineered Fe/Co/Ni catalysts with specific construction strategies, desired induced effects, enhanced catalytic mechanism in the OER electrocatalysis, which can provide deep understanding and insights in further designing high valence metals-based electrocatalysts. Finally, the challenges and future perspectives in the rapidly developing field of high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts are highlighted. 2 OER catalytic mechanism The OER is usually carried out via four proton/electron-coupled processes in alkaline condition and the hydroxyl groups tend to form oxygen and water molecules [76–79]. The OER steps involve different adsorption and desorption energy of reactants and products as well as various reaction intermediates (Fig. 2 a), including O*, HO*, and HOO*, resulting in the complexity of OER mechanism [80–82]. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the OER elementary step with the largest free-energy change is the potential-determining step (PDS), which also refers to “thermodynamic bottleneck”, while the free-energy span from the intermediate with the smallest free energy to the transition state with highest free energy refers to the rate-determining step (RDS), which is the “kinetic bottleneck” [19,83–88]. The PDS does not necessarily coincide with RDS and PDS = RDS can be achieved at the high overpotential regime. It should be mentioned that the design of OER catalytic materials is still based on the thermodynamic consideration of binding energy, that is, PDS. The OER steps involve the formation of oxygenated intermediates in most catalytic systems, such as O* or HOO* intermediates, thus the binding energy between oxygen-containing intermediates and the active sites is the key to determining the performance of the catalysts [89]. For the ideal catalyst, the free energy of each reaction step is the same, and the equilibrium potential of the OER is 1.23 V vs. RHE [25,90–92]. Norskov et al. deeply explored the reaction steps through density function theoretical (DFT) calculation and Sabatier principle combined with the Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) type relation at zero overpotential, proposed the thermodynamic overpotential (η TD) as the activity descriptor, and linked the η TD with ΔG O*-ΔG HO* [93–95]. η TD can be used to analyze the thermodynamics reaction intermediates [19,96]. Generally, smaller thermodynamic overpotentials indicate superior catalytic activity. η TD is a thermodynamic measure for the activity, which is reconciled with PDS instead of RDS. As mentioned above, the PDS and RDS may be different, thus the η TD cannot regenerate the activity trends correctly in a series of catalysts [97–101]. Moreover, η TD only considers a single free-energy change, making it actually too simplistic. The electrochemical-step symmetry index (ESSI) has been developed to compensate for some shortcomings of η TD [102]. ESSI considers all free-energy changes in the OER process with ΔG j values above 0 eV (U = 1.23 V vs. RHE), which has been regarded as a more balanced thermodynamic activity descriptor compared to that of η TD [103,104]. However, the ESSI also depends on the thermodynamic considerations, and the kinetics and applied overpotential are not included in the analysis of the free-energy changes [26,105–107]. G ma x(η), on the other hand, covers the thermodynamic consideration, kinetics and applied overpotential, which is an overpotential-dependent activity descriptor and does not rely on the precondition of PDS = RDS, indicating G ma x(η) can be evaluated at any applied overpotential [86,87]. OER with multistep electron transfer, and various intermediates in the reaction processes, results in complicated and unclear catalytic mechanism [108]. Currently, adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) are two traditional mechanisms in OER process. In AEM process, it is believed that the metal center is the only active site for OER reaction, thus the strength of the adsorption energy between the OER intermediates and the active sites is the key to determining the catalytic activity, such as the current density, η TD, etc. The reaction process of AEM under alkaline conditions is as follows (Fig. 2c). Alkaline conditions. OH−+*→HO*+e− HO*+OH−→O*+H2O + e− O*+OH−→HOO*+e− HOO*+OH−→O2 + H2O + e−+* The * represents the active sites. In the AEM mechanism, since there is a linear relationship between the adsorption energy of HO* and HOO*, according to Sabatier principle and BEP type relation, there is a universal volcanic relationship between ΔG O*-ΔG HO* and η TD [109,110]. As the linear scaling relationships exist for the η TD and ESSI, and weak scaling between the η TD and G ma x(η), the relationship can also be observed between ΔG O*-ΔG HO* and ESSI/G ma x(η). Therefore, it is necessary to adjust ΔG O*-ΔG HO* to achieve the optimized OER catalytic performance. Theoretically, due to the linear scaling relationship between the adsorption energies of HO* and HOO*, the scaling-relation intercept (SRI) of 2.46 eV (2 × 1.23 eV = 2.46 eV) is larger than the theoretical optimal value of 3.2 eV, so there is a minimum theoretical overpotential of 0.37 V ((3.2 eV − 2.46 eV)/2e = 0.37 V) under the AEM mechanism [25]. However, in experimental conditions, the SRI highly depends on the properties of the designed catalysts and the properties of the solvents, thus the reported catalysts can achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with η< 0.37 V [44,45,53]. In addition to AEM, LOM is the most widely recognized and established in recent years [111]. In LOM, the active center of OER is not limited to metals, lots of studies have shown that lattice oxygen can also play a significant role in the OER process [109]. The LOM mechanism steps shown in Fig. 2(d) are as follows. Alkaline conditions. OH−+*→HO*+H2O + e− HO*+OH−→O*+H2O + e− O*+OL → O2 + VO OH−+VO → HO*+e− H*+OH−→*+H2O + e− Where OL and VO represent lattice oxygen and surface oxygen vacancies, respectively. There is a key oxygen vacancy formation step in LOM, stimulating the degradation process (e.g., detachment of metal ions), and leading to the instability of the catalysts, which has been considered as the main reason for the poor long-term stability of OER electrocatalysts [112–122]. However, the influence of the dissolved metal ions in the electrolyte has been ignored. The dissolution of metal ions into the solution caused by LOM in the OER process may generate additional driving force and affect the long-term catalytic activity of the electrocatalysts, which may also be the reason for the catalysts showing the degradation phenomenon [123]. The main difference between AEM and LOM is how the OO step can be coupled. Since the oxidation intermediates in LOM can be directly coupled with lattice oxygen to form OO bond, it shows faster reaction kinetics [124]. However, in the actual OER process, the two mechanisms often exist at the same time and compete with each other, and the covalent state of metal–oxygen bond (M−O) has a certain influence on the catalytic reaction mechanism. LOM mechanism tends to occur when the covalence of metal–oxygen bond (M−O) increases [125]. Although the OER activity of LOM is improved compared to that of AEM, it is often accompanied by metal dissolution and structural instability [126]. Therefore, balancing the relationship between them is conducive to the development of efficient and stable catalysts [127]. In addition to AEM and LOM, the oxide path mechanism (OPM) has been proposed as follows [128]. M + OH−→M−OH + e− 2 M−OH → M−O + M + H2O 2 M−O → 2 M + O2 In OPM, the reaction intermediates are only O* and HO*. The OO bond can be directly coupled without lattice oxygen and no oxygen vacancy will be generated, thus avoiding the dissolution of catalysts. Ideally, OPM catalytic mechanism can overcome the catalytic activity limitation of AEM and the stability drawbacks of LOM in OER process. 3 The construction strategies and function of high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based OER electrocatalysts The high valence metals themselves have not been investigated widely for OER due to their limited catalytic activity. It is much more common to explore the high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts to adjust the overall structural and electronic properties, achieving the optimized OER catalytic performance. Therefore, the construction strategies of high valence metals-engineered catalysts have been intensively investigated. Generally, there are two efficient ways to prepare the high valence metals-engineered catalysts, high-valence metals as dopants and construction of the heterostructures between the high valence metal compounds and Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. These two construction approaches will highly influence the properties of active sites and thus enhance the catalytic capability of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. 3.1 High-valence metals as dopants for the Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts The high valence metals as dopants to engineer Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts are effective in achieving even distribution of high valence metals in the catalysts. The doping amount of the high valence metals plays a significant role in determining the catalytic capability. Therefore, suitable preparation methods should be investigated to control the doping amount easily and accurately to achieve the satisfied OER performance. High valence metal doping can be easily realized by hydrothermal/solvothermal method, template method, sol–gel method, etc. For instance, Mo doped Co3O4 nanosheets (Mo-Co3O4) grown on nickel foam substrate were prepared by solvothermal method [65]. The achieved ultrathin Mo-Co3O4 nanosheet arrays composed of Mo-Co3O4 nanoparticles with a diameter of 10 nm showed homogeneous distribution of Mo and Co elements on the nanosheets, leading to excellent OER performance. Sol-gel method has also been widely used to obtain the high valence metals doped materials due to the mild reaction conditions, controlled particle sizes and the homogeneous doping at the atomic level. The selection of metal precursors and solvents for the sol–gel process is significantly important as the hydrolysis rate of metal species plays a key role in the final products. For example, inorganic metal chlorides have been selected as metal precursors and ethanol was used as solvent to prepare FeCoW via sol–gel process at room temperature [60]. Due to the different hydrolysis rates of metal precursors, a low concentration of water and propylene oxide have been introduced to independently adjust the hydrolysis rate of each metal to finally achieve the uniform distribution of Fe, Co, W in the product of FeCoW, which exhibited excellent OER performance in alkaline media. The melt spinning technique has been developed to prepare the catalysts with high valence metals as dopants. The melt spinning method can take melted metal as raw material and spin it through a melt spinning machine. Different composition materials can be synthesized by configuring different proportions of spinning size, and the adjustment of material structure can be realized by changing spinning conditions. During the preparation of Al95.9Co0.1Fe1Mo1Cr1Pt0.1 alloy, the pure metals were melted in an electric arc furnace to prepare the alloy precursors before melt spinning [129]. By setting the tangential speed of the copper roller at 45 m s−1, the width of ∼2 mm and the thickness of ∼20 μm high valence metals and precious metal alloy strip can be obtained. In addition, electrodeposition can also be used to prepare the high valence metals-based catalysts, and the doping amount of the final catalyst can be flexibly controlled. The current, pH and temperature of the electrolyte, and the additives can affect the morphology and composition of the synthesized catalysts. For example, citric acid as an additive can change the reduction potential of metal ions, L-ascorbic acid can avoid the oxidation of metal ions to a certain extent, and high pH makes them easier to form hydroxides, thus affecting the current efficiency and catalyst composition [130–133]. As shown in Fig. 3 , the incorporation of metal ions (Fe, V, Co, Ni) into MnO2 ultrathin nanosheets can be achieved by an anodic coprecipitation process [134]. H2SO4 was selected as the electrolyte and sodium vanadate was used as the metal vanadium source. The anodic electrodeposition was carried out under the current density of 3 mA cm−2 and electrolysis temperature of 98 °C. During the deposition process, the valence state of V in NaVO3 was kept unchanged [135–138]. V was successfully doped to replace Mn, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancies and increasing the density of active sites. Cr doped NiFe (oxy)hydroxide and Ce doped NiFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) can also be prepared via the similar electrodeposition processes [139,140]. 3.2 The heterostructures constructed between the high valence metal compounds and Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts In addition to acting as dopants, high valence metals can also engineer the Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts via forming heterostructures. By combining different components to build heterostructures, the synergistic effect, strain effect and electron interaction can be produced at the interface, which is conducive to boosted OER performance. The synthesis of heterogeneous structures of high valence metals and Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts can be achieved through the combination of electrochemical strategy, hydrothermal, coprecipitation, and other suitable synthesis methods [141]. For instance, (WO2-Na x WO3)@FeOOH/NF composite with coating architecture was achieved in three steps [142]. Firstly, (WO2-Na x WO3)/NF was obtained by hydrothermal and high temperature annealing. Then, FeOOH coating layers were obtained by soaking (WO2-Na x WO3)/NF in an aqueous solution containing Fe3+ at 100 °C, in which the strong hydrolysis effect of Fe3+ resulted in the interface reaction to promote the formation of FeOOH. The achieved special interface structure between FeOOH and WO2-Na x WO3 was conducive to the electron redistribution to optimize the binding energy of H2O/OH− at the active sites, improving the OER performance. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4 (a and b), molybdenum disulfide and hydrotalcite composites (MoS2@NiFeCr-LDH) can be prepared by coprecipitation and hydrothermal methods [143]. Firstly, NiFeCr-LDHs were prepared by mixing nickel (Ⅱ) nitrate and ferric (III) nitrate solution with sodium molybdate and sodium hydroxide solution, followed by the heat treatment. After that, thiourea, hydrazine hydrate and NiFeCr-LDH were ultrasonically mixed and calcined in a muffle furnace at 200 °C for 12 h to successfully prepare the MoS2@NiFeCr-LDH composite. The surface of the MoS2@NiFeCr-LDH composite was loose, and the layer spacing was larger than that of the original NiFeCr-LDH, exposing more active sites and improving the electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 4c–f). 4 The induced effects by high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts High valence metals engineering Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts can induce various effects to modify the OER catalytic performance. For instance, the high valence metals in Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts can promote the efficient generation of relatively high valence Fe/Co/Ni active sites by accelerating the initial reconstruction process to achieve the satisfied OER performance. The high valence metals can also effectively induce the formation of an amorphous structure for Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts, resulting in unique catalytic properties. Moreover, high valence metals can boost the OER activity of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts via the formation of defects/vacancies. The high valence metals can also work as stabilizers in Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts due to their unique valence state and charge density characteristics, which is a key aspect in the OER process. 4.1 Accelerating surface reconstruction to form Fe/Co/Ni with relatively higher valence states It has been found that the Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts with relatively higher valence states often lead to superior activity [49,144]. The experiments showed that the real active species might be different from the initial catalyst in the actual reaction process. The species of Fe/Co/Ni often undergo surface reconstruction to produce high valence sites, which is the key process enhancing the electrocatalytic activity [53,145]. Thus, high valence metals doping can accelerate the formation of high valence Fe/Co/Ni-based sites by promoting the initial surface reconstruction and pre-activation of the catalysts, which is very beneficial to OER [145–147]. The partial or total surface reconstruction can be realized by the dissolution or leaching of high valence metals. For instance, as shown in Fig. 5 (a and b), the in-situ dissolution of MoO4 2− well facilitated the surface reconstruction of CoMoO4 to Co3O4/CoMoO4 and CoOOH/CoMoO4 heterostructures. The partial electron transfer from Co to Mo atoms after activation and reconstruction, induced the formation of high valence Co species (Fig. 5c and d), which contributed to the superior OER activity (Fig. 5e and f) [146]. Besides, the unique electronic structure of high valence metals can also induce the surface reconstruction and formation of Fe/Co/Ni-based high valence sites to promote the OER performance [148–150]. In the research of Kang et al., the heterogeneous catalysts containing W utilized the electronic coupling effect on the heterogeneous interface to stimulate the surface reconstruction process [151]. The formed strong electronic interaction between W nanoparticles and CoO nanowire arrays promoted the electron transfer, and thus accelerated the formation of oxyhydroxide species (CoOOH) and the OER kinetics. 4.2 Inducing the formation of amorphous structure The electrocatalysts with an amorphous structure may induce superior OER electrocatalytic performance to compare to their corresponding crystalline catalysts, due to their phase separation in OER process, which may reduce the corresponding catalytic capability and complicate the reaction mechanism study [70,152,153]. The amorphous property can facilitate the charge transfer between the intermediates and the active sites. Furthermore, amorphous materials possess macroscopic uniformity and can be considered homogeneous catalysts. High valence metals are conducive to the formation of an amorphous structure for the OER catalysts and promote the OER process. As shown in Fig. 6 (a and b), CoV hydroxide prepared by one-step coprecipitation method showed ultrathin amorphous structure (CoV-UAH), whereas the crystal structure derived in the vanadium-free sample of cobalt hydroxide nanosheets (Co-UH) [154]. The formation of amorphous structure is attributed to the lattice mismatch resulting from [VO4] induced distorted adjacent coordination of surrounding Co and O. Compared with Co-UH achieving the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of 300 mV, CoV-UAH only needed 250 mV to achieve the same current density (Fig. 6d). In addition, ultrafine CoMn-LDH nanoplates possessed much higher activity than both bulk and exfoliated CoCo and NiCo-LDH [155]. As shown in Fig. 6(c, f, and g), the study showed that Mn ions were leached and formed the amorphous surface phases within the first 3 h of the OER. Moreover, in these amorphous regions, the unsaturated coordination sites and the accumulated Co4+ species can further enhance the catalytic activity (Fig. 6e). Except for directly facilitating the formation of an amorphous structure, the leaching property of high valence metals in the OER process can also result in a partially amorphous interface structure. For instance, the introduction of Cr changed the coordination environment of Ni, Fe, and Co in the (CrFeCoNi)97O3 high-entropy alloys(O-HEAs) [156]. The inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) results showed that the leaching amount of Cr element was much higher than other elements, and Cr leaching promoted charge transfer and accelerated the surface reconstruction, resulting in amorphous regions on the surface of the catalyst. 4.3 The formation of vacancies/defects High valence metals can adjust and optimize the OER activity via the formation of non-metal or metal vacancies [157]. The oxygen vacancies can be induced by the direct incorporation of high valence metals or their dissociation property [145,146]. The formed oxygen vacancies can make the delocalized electrons more easily excite to the conduction band, which can improve the conductivity of the catalysts [158]. Yu et al. prepared high-efficiency OER catalyst CeO2- x -FeNi, ascribing to the oxygen vacancies rich structure of CeO2 (Fig. 7 a–c), innovatively realized the formation of high active Ni3+ or even Ni4+ species under mild conditions [159]. As shown in Fig. 7(d–f), when Ni2+ ions were doped into the catalyst through substitution reaction, they will be further oxidized to form high valence Ni3+/Ni4+ by the adjacent Ce ions and oxygen vacancies. Oxygen vacancies on the surface of metal oxides can adjust their physical and chemical properties [160]. Due to the existence of oxygen vacancies, the catalysts will produce an unsaturated coordination environment to regulate the electronic environment of the surrounding atoms, which can change the adsorption energy of the active sites, thus changing the RDS of OER [161]. In addition, the regulation of the surrounding metal orbitals by oxygen defects can also affect the conductivity [162]. The oxygen vacancies in the perovskite structure can be used as a charged species to enhance the charge transfer rate between the intermediates and the active sites, which is beneficial to OER. The radius difference between Nb3+ and Ba2+ resulted in the formation of oxygen vacancies in Nd1.5Ba1.5CoFeMnO9-δ (NBCFM) and the concentration of the oxygen vacancies can be adjusted by changing the oxidation state of Mn [163,164]. The overpotential of NBCFM was only 359 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in the OER process. Defect sites, such as vacancies and grain boundaries, can regulate the overall electrocatalytic activity by adjusting electronic properties or acting as additional active sites. In the synthesis design of the heterostructure interface CoSe2-MoSe2/poly 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene (PEDOT), Se deficient catalysts were constructed by adjusting the ratio between Se and Co during the formation of CoSe2, and these VSe point defects will further reorganize in the subsequent thermal annealing process to form extended dislocations and grain boundaries [165]. Thus, Mo–Mo interaction will be enhanced to form stable metal defect sites, Mo–Mo bond defects. The VSe and Mo–Mo bond defects in CoSe2-MoSe2/PEDOT will destroy the lattice arrangement and lead to additional active sites and increase affinity for reactant intermediates. In addition, Mo–Mo bond defects can also lead to better electron transport performance of the catalyst due to their metallic properties. 4.4 Stabilizer Due to their unique d-band center and electronic structure, high valence metals can act as “electronic storage” in the catalysis reaction process to improve structural stability [166,167]. The strong electron absorption ability of high valence metals promotes the electron transfer from the Fe/Co/Ni to the high valence metals, stabilizing these high valence states active sites [168,169]. Mo doped Co3O4 nanoparticles coated carbon nanotubes (Mo-Co3O4/CNTs) exhibited excellent OER activity and durability [170]. The initial potential was as low as 1.42 V and the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 was only 280 mV. Mo doping induced the d-band electron transfer from Co2+ to Mo6+, facilitating the adsorption and reaction of OH−, and realizing the formation and maintenance of a high proportion of Co2+ active sites in the OER process, which led to the excellent OER stability of only increasing 6 mV overpotential for 30 h under the chronoamperometric experiment. In addition, the redox reaction behavior of high valence metals can also stabilize the active centers. Since the OER activity of β-NiOOH (Ni≤ 3+) is higher than that of γ-NiOOH (Ni with a higher oxidation state, such as Ni3.7+), it is necessary to avoid the peroxidation of Ni in the OER process. In the FeNiCr catalyst, the valence state of Ni can maintain at 2–3+ during OER process, whereas the valence state of Ni increased to 3–4+ in the absence of Cr (Fig. 8 a–c, i, and j), suggesting the oxidation of Cr can protect Ni from peroxidation in NiOOH active intermediates during the reaction (Fig. 8k and l) [139]. As the Cr K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) results are shown in Fig. 8(d–h), it is proved that most of the oxidation reactions preferentially occur on Cr under applied external voltage. In addition, it was found that W added to NiFe could stabilize the Ni and Fe active sites through the reduction of W in the OER process [171]. In the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum after long term-chronopotentiometry, the state of Ni3+ increased slightly, and the Fe2+/3+ ratio changed slightly, while the peak value of W moved to lower binding energy, indicating that W was reduced to form a lower oxidation state in the OER process to stabilize Ni and Fe active sites. Moreover, the addition of W can change the local environment of Ni and Fe, adjust their electronic structure, and produce oxygen vacancies, thus producing many OER active sites. The doping amount of W can also affect the internal electronic coupling degree of NiFe, and then regulate the chemisorption capacity of hydroxyl and oxygen intermediates. The catalyst can reach a high current density of 50 mA cm−2 with only 251 mV low overpotential, and only 4 mV overpotential was increased after 24 h operation under this current density. The effects induced by high valence metals are commonly not isolated, and they are complex, unseparated, and interrelated. For instance, the introduction of high valence metals leads to the change of oxygen vacancies concentration and the formation of heterostructures simultaneously, which directly regulate the electronic structure of materials. W-doped FeNi-LDH (FeNiW-LDH) prepared by the electrochemical etching method showed that W-doping had a significant effect on increasing the concentration of oxygen vacancies, which was conducive to the exposure of active sites [172]. Furthermore, theoretical calculations showed that oxygen vacancies can adjust the electronic structure of FeNi-LDH to optimize the adsorption of intermediates and accelerate the OER kinetics. In addition, the incorporation of W18O49 into W18O49/NiWO4 heterojunction also induced several effects to boost the OER performance [173]. After reconstruction, the original catalyst will become NiWO4/NiOOH with the amorphous interface. Moreover, the incorporation of W ions resulted in the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies. The high proportion of unsaturated tetravalent W and trivalent Ni ions as the active centers of OER are mutually stable, so the activated electrocatalyst showed excellent OER activity and maintained long-term stability for more than 100 h under the current density of 10 mA cm−2. 5 The high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts with specific induced effects for OER electrocatalysis High valence metals engineering strategies play a key role in determining the catalytic activity of OER catalysts. As shown in Table 1 , recently, the research on high valence metals engineered catalysts has received intense attention. The introduction of high valence metals can optimize the surface reconstruction process of the pre-catalyst (Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts) and improve the OER performance. In addition, due to their characteristics of the high valence and multivalent states, the high valence metals can interact with the Fe/Co/Ni ions, adjusting the electronic structure and optimizing their OER capability. Moreover, the ability to pull electrons of high valence metals makes them act as electron acceptors, which play important roles in stabilizing the catalyst in the OER process. Furthermore, the specific properties of the high valence metals enable them to adjust the morphology, structure, and phase composition of the as-prepared catalysts, which has attracted extensive attention in the aspect of catalyst design. In this section, we will focus on the high valence metal, including Mo, W, Ce, V, Cr, Mn, and Nb, Zr, engineered catalysts with specific induced effects for the boosted OER performance. 5.1 Mo-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis As the electrons in the 5s and 4d orbitals of Mo atoms are half-filled, it has a variety of valence states, such as +4, and +6. The multivalent states of Mo are conducive to engineering the catalysts, and the strong electronic interaction between Mo and other metals highly enhances the OER catalytic activity [174,175]. Mo has been widely investigated as dopant to engineer the Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalysts [147,176]. The Mo doped Co(OH)2 nanofilms coupled with CoP nanosheets supported on nickel foam (MoCo(OH)2/CoP/NF) had been prepared via electrodeposition phosphating electrodeposition strategy [177]. Mo doping reduced the thickness and formed a porous crumpled structure, resulting in the increase of exposed active sites. Therefore, the incorporated Mo atoms increased the active centers of Co(OH)2 nanosheets and improved the electrochemical catalytic activity. Fe and Mo co-doped Ni(OH)2/NiOOH nanosheets displayed a significant synergistic effect between Mo and Fe, which increased the interaction with the HO* on the active sites and improved the OER activity (Fig. 9 a and b) [178]. XPS showed that a significant shift of the high-resolution Ni peak with the addition of Fe and Mo occurred compared to the addition of Fe or Mo alone (Fig. 9c), demonstrating the synergistic effect of Mo and Fe co-doping. Electrochemical tests showed that MoFe:Ni(OH)2/NiOOH only needed 280 mV overpotential for the current density of 100 mA cm−2, and there was no degradation after 50 h test (Fig. 9d and e). The introduction of Mo can efficiently promote the pre-activation process of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts via the dissolution and redistribution of Mo, species leaching, and special structure induced, thus optimizing their OER performance. NiMoO4 nanowires modified by FeOOH underwent rapid reconstruction during OER induced by the Mo leaching, resulting in the formation of truly active species, Ni(Fe)OOH [147]. It is worth mentioning that the activity and stability of formed amorphous Ni(Fe)OOH after reconstruction were extremely excellent. Only 253 mV was required to achieve a high current density of 100 mA cm−2. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves before and after the 3000 cycles and 20 h chronoamperometric test at 100 mA cm−2 were almost unchanged, demonstrating excellent stability. In addition, NiMoO4@Co3O4 core–shell nanorods also demonstrated Mo leaching in the OER process can result in a rough and porous surface, which was conducive to electrolyte penetration [179]. It is worth noting that dissolved Mo in the surface reconstruction process will lead to the inside active centers exposed on the surface, boosting the OER catalytic activity. Moreover, the long-term stability test revealed that the Mo leaching had no impact on the morphology and catalytic performance. Except for structural reconstruction, the introduction of Mo can also induce the formation of amorphous structure. As shown in Fig. 10 (a–c), Mo doping induced the formation of amorphous nickel cobaltate nanoneedles on nickel foam (Mo-NiCo2O4/NF) with a porous hierarchical structure by hydrothermal method, which increased the specific surface area and electron transport efficiency. Mo-NiCo2O4/NF realized the low Tafel slope of 43 mV dec−1 (Fig. 10d and e) [180]. The rapid spontaneous surface reconstruction resulted in the formation of oxygen vacancies, which further improved the catalyst activity. In addition, Mo single atom (16 wt%) doped CoOOH can result in the Mo active sites on the basal plane (Mo-CoOOH), improving the OER activity [181]. The Mo K-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra showed that Mo can be incorporated into the CoOOH lattice and had a lower oxidation state than MoO3, which was attributed to the low valence Mo in cobalt-2-methylimidazole (ZIF-67) with an octahedral structure similar to CoOOH. Experiments and calculations showed that Mo confined in the lattice can promote electron transfer, and Mo on the base plane can replace Co as the active centers for OER. Therefore, lattice-limited Mo in 3D nanoframes of ultrathin Mo-CoOOH nanosheets can enhance the OER activity by increasing conductivity and inducing abundant active sites. The Mo engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts can not only improve the OER catalytic activity but also improve the stability. For instance, Mo-doped porous CoFe LDH/NF catalyst had been prepared by electrochemical transformation of Mo-doped CoFe Prussian blue nanocubes on nickel foam (Mo-doped CoFe PBA/NF) [58]. Mo doping produced abundant edge defects and exposed more active sites. At the same time, the high valence Mo had a strong electron absorption ability, which can well adjust the electronic structure to stabilize the Co and Fe active centers in the OER process. In addition, the content of the Mo dopant was optimized. It was found that the best catalytic performance can be achieved when the molar ratio of Mo to Fe is 1:10. In an alkaline environment, only 331 mV overpotential was required to achieve a current density of 100 mA cm−2, and the long-term stability test showed the current density maintained at 92.8% after 24 h continuous test. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) result had almost no obvious decay before and after cycling, which further confirmed the excellent stability. 5.2 W-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis W usually exists at relatively high valence states with high charge density, which makes it has a strong ability to pull electrons and forms strong electronic interaction with low valence Fe/Co/Ni species. The specific structure of the outermost empty orbit makes W possess the capability to adjust the electronic structure and local coordination environment of the as-prepared materials. Incorporating W into the catalysts may induce specific effects, such as homogeneous amorphous surfaces, heterostructures, defects, etc. For example, W dissolution induces the formation of oxygen vacancy is one of the most common and effective means to regulate the properties of W-based catalysts during the OER process. Fan et al. proposed a unique method to prepare CoFe (oxy)hydroxide catalyst with rich OER active centers by etching W during the self-reconstruction from CoFeWS to CoFe (oxy)hydroxide [145]. In this process, the metal ion vacancies have been generated and promoted the formation of high valence Co sites (Co3+), which contributed to the high OER performance. Specifically, after optimizing the composition, Co0.6Fe0.2W0.2Sδ exhibited the best OER activity with a current density of 128 mA cm−2 at 350 mV overpotential. Furthermore, LSV and chronoamperometry studies verified that the complete etching of W did not affect the type of active species or OER mechanism in the CoFe (oxy) hydroxide catalyst. In addition, W dissociation to facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies also occurred in the amorphous Co(OH)2/WO x catalysts (a-CoW) (Fig. 11 a), which promoted the rapid surface reconstruction and improved the OER performance [182]. As shown in Fig. 11(b and c), a-CoW achieved a low overpotential of 208 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and remained stable for more than 120 h. W6+ doped Ni(OH)2/NiOOH nanosheets grown vertically on carbon cloth had been prepared by electrodeposition and hydrothermal methods [59]. Through changing the content of dopant (W6+), it was determined that W0.1Ni(OH)2/NiOOH nanosheets had the best electrocatalysis efficiency. In an alkaline medium, only 293 mV was needed to reach the current density of 50 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope was as low as 48.2 mV dec−1 and durable up to 120 h. The results showed that W6+ in W0.1Ni(OH)2/NiOOH nanosheets is a d0 system with the ability to pull electrons from other metal ions, resulting in the production of Ni3+. Moreover, the theoretical calculation also revealed that the synergistic effect between Ni2+ and W6+ was beneficial for OER process, decreasing the Gibbs free energy. In addition, W atom substituted perovskite oxide nanowires (Pr0.5Ba0.5Co1 − x W x O3 − σ ) had been synthesized by electrospinning [183]. Specifically, the Pr0.5Ba0.5Co0.8W0.2O3 − δ showed the best performance, exhibiting an overpotential of 325 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and maintaining the current density for more than 10000 s. The characterization results demonstrated that the outermost vacancy orbital of W can efficiently optimize the electronic structure of the Co sites, adjusting the local coordination environment to form the real active sites (CoOOH), thus, boosting the intrinsic OER activity. The unique electronic structure of W makes it possible to adjust the adsorption of intermediates on the as-prepared catalysts. The homogeneous dispersed multimetal FeCoW catalyst has been prepared by sol–gel method [60]. The DFT results demonstrated that the adsorption energy of HO* on pure β-CoOOH, WO3, and γ-FeOOH phases are different, in which the adsorption energy on the (010) surface of FeOOH is too strong, whereas it is too weak on CoOOH and WO3. The optimized HO* adsorption energy can be achieved by forming multimetal FeCoW catalyst, leading to excellent OER catalytic activity. Therefore, FeCoW only needed 191 mV overpotential to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and there was no sign of degradation after 500 h test. 5.3 Ce-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis High valence Ce can engineer the properties of the catalysts by forming the special structure of CeO2, which are usually rich with oxygen vacancies. For instance, the CeO2/NiFeCo composite with rich oxygen vacancies in amorphous CeO2 structure highly boosted the OER performance, achieving a low overpotential of 260 mV for the current density of 10 mA cm−2 [184]. In addition, CeO x /CoO x had been prepared by electrodeposition, and the introduction of Ce led to the formation of highly oxidized Co active species (CoOOH) [185]. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 12 (a and b), the results demonstrated that the presence of CeO2 can generate the new active sites of CoOOH and optimize the binding energy of intermediates and new active sites (Fig. 12d and e), thus enhancing the catalytic activity [186,187]. At the current density of 10 mA cm−2, it only needed the overpotential of 313 mV (Fig. 12c). 5.4 V-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis Element V, as a high valence metal, possesses multivalent states, making it a promising dopant to enhance the catalytic capability of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 12(g–j), in Ni3Fe1− x V x /Ni3Fe1− x V x N heterojunction, V3+/V4+ had a variable valence electron acceptor, so the electrons transfer between the intermediates and amorphous NiFeOOH in the OER process can be effectively accelerated [188]. In addition, high valence V can also act as an electron acceptor to absorb electrons from Ni2+ to facilitate the formation of Ni3+, further boosting the OER kinetics. Ni3Fe1− x V x /Ni3Fe1− x V x N exhibited overpotentials of only 113 and 226 mV at 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively. In the nanocomposite CoV/CF-CWs, the introduction of V can efficiently adjust the d-band center and change the local coordination of Co–O, thus increasing the oxygen and Co vacancies and enhancing the OER performance [189]. Furthermore, the formed Co–O–V bond can further promote the direct coupling of OO bond. 5.5 Cr-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis The electronic regulation of Cr can also promote the structural reconstruction and the formation of high valence species of Fe/Co/Ni. In order to study the role of Cr in transition metal oxide OER catalyst and the optimal element composition of the catalyst, Chen et al. combined with theoretical calculation guidance, prepared a series of ternary CoaFebCrc by coprecipitation method, among which Co5Fe3Cr2 was the most suitable element composition (Fig. 13 a and b) [53]. Quasi operando electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) results demonstrated that Cr can change the electronic structure of Co5Fe3Cr2, promoting the Co occupation in octahedral sites. As shown in Fig. 13(c), the synergistic effect of Cr and Co changed the corresponding electronic state, accelerated the formation of high valence Co species (Co3+ and Co4+), and enhanced their OER activity. In addition, the amorphous structure of Co5Fe3Cr2 also played a key role in the excellent OER activity when compared to the controlled sample prepared by thermal annealing Co5Fe3Cr2 (a-Co5Fe3Cr2) containing separated crystallinity structure. Co5Fe3Cr2 achieved the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of only 232 mV, which was much superior compared with the a-Co5Fe3Cr2 is 373 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13d and e). The incorporation of Cr into Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts can also improve the conductivity and increase the active sites for boosted OER performance [139,190]. For instance, nanoneedles shaped Cr doped NiCo2O4 (Cr-NiCo2O4 NNs) grown on NF have been achieved by a simple hydrothermal route followed by annealing. Cr acts as an electron donor increasing its electron density, resulting in enhanced conductivity [190]. The high conductivity can connect the distal end of NNs to the conductive substrate NF, thereby increasing the number of active sites on NNs. 5.6 Mn-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis The incorporation of high valence Mn may affect the properties of the catalysts, such as inducing structural defects, and amorphous structures, promoting the formation of Fe/Co/Ni high valence sites and improving stability. Ultrathin amorphous MnO2 modified shrimp shell derived porous carbon (U-MnO2/PSNC) had been prepared by self-template assisted pyrolysis [191]. The results showed that the introduction of MnO2 was beneficial to the high OER activity due to the inherent rich surface defects, the homogeneous active centers, and the strong chemical bonding effect with carbon materials. U-MnO2/PSNC also showed OER catalytic stability maintaining 87.18% in chronoamperometry test. MnO2 modified Co(OH)2 (Co(OH)2@MnO2) heterostructure grown directly on carbon paper (Co(OH)2@MnO2-CNAs) had also been investigated [192]. The existence of MnO2 in heterostructure facilitated the conversion of Co2+ to Co3+, boosting the OER process. DFT calculation further confirmed the formation of Mn-O bonds and HO hydrogen bonds between Co(OH)2 and MnO2, resulting in the higher positive charge density of Co atoms in the Co(OH)2@MnO2 heterostructure compared to those in the bulk Co(OH)2. This demonstrated that MnO2 can efficiently induce electronic modification of Co(OH)2, resulting in charge redistribution and enhanced catalytic activity. Co(OH)2@MnO2 exhibited a constant current density of 10 mA cm−2 for 18 h with almost no attenuation of overpotential. Mn-doped NiFe-LDH/reduced graphene oxide (Mn-NiFe-LDH/rGO) had also been prepared by hydrothermal method to investigate the role Mn atoms on the OER performance (Fig. 13f) [193]. As shown in Fig. 13(h), experiments and calculations results showed that the introduction of Mn dopant can optimize the electronic structure of NiFe-LDH, and appropriate content of Mn can optimize the adsorption of OER intermediate O* on the Fe active sites, thus reducing the RDS energy barrier and accelerating the OER reaction kinetic. Mn-NiFe LDH/rGO exhibited a low Tafel slope of 40 mV dec−1, and only needed 240 mV overpotential to deliver the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13g). 5.7 Nb-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis The highly positive charge density of Nb5+ makes it possible to adjust the electronic structure of the surrounding atoms, and it may also facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies, which are conducive to OER. For example, porous Nb-Co4N nanosheets with large specific surface area and exposed active sites, exhibited excellent OER catalytic capability [61]. The results demonstrated that the incorporated Nb replaced the position of Co atoms, adjusting the electronic structure of Nb-Co4N and facilitating the formation of many Co3+ active sites. Therefore, Nb-Co4N delivered excellent OER catalytic activity with 273 mV overpotential to achieve the current density of 20 mA cm−2. Nb as a high valence metal dopant can also lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 14 (a), Nb atoms occupied the relatively lower valence state of Co sites in Sr0.5Ba0.5Nb2 − x Co x O6 of tetragonal bronze tungsten structure (TTB), due to the similar radii of Nb5+ and Co2+. However, the difference in valence state between Nb and Co led to the generation of a large number of surface oxygen vacancies, which can stabilize Co2+ and enhance structural stability (Fig. 14b–h) [62]. 5.8 Zr-engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for OER electrocatalysis Zr as higher valence metal compared to Fe/Co/Ni can induce strong electronic interaction with Fe/Co/Ni atoms to enhance the conductivity and boost the OER performance [194,195]. For instance, Zr doped NiFe-LDH (ZrNiFe-LDH) has been prepared by direct hydrothermal deposition and the incorporation of Zr had no influence on the morphology and crystal structure of NiFe-LDH [196]. However, the XPS results showed the peaks of Ni 2p and Fe 2p in ZrNiFe-LDH shifted to lower binding energies compared to those in NiFe-LDH, demonstrating the strong electronic interaction between Zr4+ and Fe3+/Ni2+. Moreover, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) showed small series resistances (Rs), suggesting that Zr can highly enhance the conductivity of ZrNiFe-LDH. The optimized OER catalytic activity of ZrNiFe-LDH has been achieved with the ratio of Ni:Fe:Zr = 4:1:1, showing the overpotential of 198 mV to deliver the current density of 10 mA cm−2. In addition, the in-situ formed Zr doped Ni(OH)2 nanosheets (Zr-Ni(OH)2) also showed a strong interaction between Zr and Ni atoms, as demonstrated by the negative shift of Ni 2p [197]. Moreover, the Zr cation can also make the adjacent O atoms warp and cause the surface distortions of Ni(OH)2, resulting in the formation of rough surfaces, which corresponds well to the lattice distortion observed in high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). What’s more, the gap between Zr and adjacent O atoms will generate electron accumulation to form an unbalanced distribution of electrons, which can form a special situation with the coexistence of electron poor and rich regions to promote the adsorption of reaction intermediates and thereby enhance the catalytic performance. Zr-Ni(OH)2 exhibited excellent OER catalytic capability, achieving the current density of 500 and 1000 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of 310 and 328 mV, respectively. Moreover, the Zr doping can also affect the morphology of the Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts [63,194]. For instance, as shown in Fig. 15 (a–c), the incorporation of Zr regulated the morphology of CoFe2O4 from irregular nanoparticles (no Zr doping) to nanosheets [63]. However, excessive content of Zr resulted in the deterioration of morphology, and the large-sized stacked nanoparticles were formed after the content of Zr reached 10%. The morphology regulation led to more exposure of active sites for OER, achieving the current density of 20 mA cm−2 with only 264 mV overpotential (Fig. 15d). 6 Conclusions and outlook OER has attracted extensive attention and become one of the most potential candidates for clean energy in the future. High valence metals have attracted considerable interest as an effective modification strategy in designing highly efficient OER catalysts. This review comprehensively summarizes the construction strategies, induced effect and the corresponding catalytic activity based on various high valence metals in the OER research field. The high valence metals doped into the Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts to enhance the OER activity. Besides, the constructed heterostructures between the high valence metal compounds and Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts can achieve the satisfied OER performance. This review also discusses the induced effects due to the presence of the high valence metals, such as accelerating surface reconstruction to form high valence species of Fe/Co/Ni, inducing the formation of amorphous structures and oxygen vacancies/defects, and acting as a “stabilizer” to keep the catalyst stable during OER. The OER application based on various high valence metals has been summarized, and the relationships between construction strategies, induced effects, reaction pathways and catalytic activity are well-developed. Although high valence metals have been extensively studied in the field of OER and achieved excellent catalytic activity, the following issues should be further considered in the research and development of high valence metals engineered catalysts. (1) The high valence metals engineering strategy provides a variety of elements for the modification of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. However, the current research focuses on the modification of Fe/Co/N-based catalysts by introducing merely-one kind of high valence metal element, while two or more high valence elements together may result in a synergistic effect in the regulation of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. For example, Mo can adjust and affect the electronic structure of the surrounding atoms, while the introduction of Ce tends to generate oxygen vacancies, which can co-boost the OER catalytic activity. Therefore, introducing a variety of different high valence metal elements to engineer Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts at the same time may be a feasible direction for the further development of highly efficient OER catalysts. (2) Facial and large-scale preparation techniques should be developed to prepare the high valence metals engineered Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. The current synthesis technology is mainly used to produce a limited number of materials studied in the laboratory, and large-scale production is still a challenge for commercial and industrial applications. Therefore, facial and large-scale preparation techniques are urgently needed for future development. In addition, it is necessary to improve the synthesis technology by using green chemical methods to reduce resource consumption and environmental pollution, and the environmental impact of the synthesis method and products before commercialization also needs to be carefully evaluated. (3) It is obvious that the introduction of high valence metals can efficiently improve the OER performance of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts. However, comprehensively understanding of the actual active sites of high valence metals engineered catalysts is lacking. Currently, most studies demonstrate that the Fe/Co/Ni sites are the actual sites, whereas the high valence metals work as the booster. More advanced techniques should be developed to further study the role the high valence metals in the OER process. Thus, it is an urgent need for in-depth research on the activity analysis of high valence metals sites in OER and in-situ technical means (such as XPS, XANES, Raman spectroscopy, etc.) to get more information. The deeper understanding of the structure–activity relationship can allow us to better apply high valence metals to the design guidance of OER catalysts. (4) There are a variety of high valence metals and they possess specific functions. Therefore, how to choose the high valence metals and identify the role of each element in OER catalysts is significantly important for the current research. DFT calculation can screen the suitable high valence metals to be used to engineer the Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for enhanced OER performance. Moreover, DFT is very effective to understand the catalytic reaction kinetics, which can help to understand the catalytic mechanism at atomic scale. Therefore, through DFT calculation and research on high valence metals, we can have a deeper understanding of the binding energy and stabilization effect of different high valence metals on intermediates in the actual reaction process, resulting in more appropriate use of high valence metals engineering strategy to adjust the Fe/Co/Ni-based OER catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis for the oxygen evolution reactions (OER) has attracted much attention due to its important role in water splitting and rechargeable metal-air batteries. Therefore, designing highly efficient and low-cost catalysts for OER process is essential as the conventional catalysts still rely on precious metals. Transition metal-based compounds have been widely investigated as active OER catalysts, and renewed interest in the high valence metals engineered compounds has been achieved for superior catalytic activity and stability. However, an in-depth understanding of the construction strategies and induced effects for the high valence metals engineered catalysts is still lacking and desired. In this review, we have summarized the construction strategies of high valence metals as dopants or formed heterostructures with the iron/cobalt/nickel (Fe/Co/Ni)-based catalysts. Then the induced effects on Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts by incorporating high valence metals, e.g., accelerating the surface reconstruction, forming amorphous structure, generating vacancies/defects, and acting as stabilizers, are highlighted. The impacts of high valence metals on OER performance are elucidated based on different elements, including molybdenum (Mo), tungsten (W), cerium (Ce), vanadium (V), chromium (Cr), manganese (Mn), niobium (Nb), zirconium (Zr). The correlations of construction strategies, induced effects, catalytic activity and OER reaction pathways are elaborated. Finally, the remaining challenges for further enhancements of OER performance induced by high valence metals are presented.

coredata.dc:title: High valence metals engineering strategies of Fe/Co/Ni-based catalysts for boosted OER electrocatalysis
